0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono:
• Bleeding - Hemophilia A: dosage calculation: body weight (kg) X factor VIII activity increase desired (%) divided by 2% per international unit per kg = dose required (international units)
  • Bleeding - Hemophilia A: mild hemorrhage: a single dose of 10 international units/kg IV to achieve a rise of approximately 20% of normal of antihemophilic factor VIII. Repeat if evidence of further bleeding
  • Bleeding - Hemophilia A: moderate hemorrhage: 15 to 25 international units/kg IV to achieve a rise of approximately 30% to 50% of normal of antihemophilic factor VIII. Repeat with 10 to 15 international units/kg IV every 8 to 12 hours if evidence of further bleeding
  • Bleeding - Hemophilia A: severe hemorrhage: initially 40 to 50 international units/kg IV; maintenance dose 20 to 25 international units/kg IV every 8 to 12 hours to achieve a rise of approximately 80% to 100% of normal of antihemophilic factor VIII
  • Bleeding - Hemophilia A - Surgical procedure: dosage calculation: body weight (kg) X factor VIII activity increase desired (%) divided by 2% per international unit per kg = dose required (international units)
  • Bleeding - Hemophilia A - Surgical procedure: surgery, major procedures: preoperatively 50 international units/kg IV to achieve a rise of approximately 100% of normal of antihemophilic factor VIII prior to surgery; repeat infusions every 6 to 12 hours initially as needed and for a total of 10 to 14 days until healing is complete

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono:
• Bleeding - Hemophilia A: dosage calculation: body weight (kg) X factor VIII activity increase desired (%) divided by 2% per international unit per kg = dose required (international units)
  • Bleeding - Hemophilia A: mild hemorrhage: a single dose of 10 international units/kg IV to achieve a rise of approximately 20% of normal of antihemophilic factor VIII. Repeat if evidence of further bleeding
  • Bleeding - Hemophilia A: moderate hemorrhage: 15 to 25 international units/kg IV to achieve a rise of approximately 30% to 50% of normal of antihemophilic factor VIII. Repeat with 10 to 15 international units/kg IV every 8 to 12 hours if evidence of further bleeding
  • Bleeding - Hemophilia A: severe hemorrhage: initially 40 to 50 international units/kg IV; maintenance dose 20 to 25 international units/kg IV every 8 to 12 hours to achieve a rise of approximately 80% to 100% of normal of antihemophilic factor VIII
  • Bleeding - Hemophilia A - Surgical procedure: dosage calculation: body weight (kg) X factor VIII activity increase desired (%) divided by 2% per international unit per kg = dose required (international units)
  • Bleeding - Hemophilia A - Surgical procedure: surgery, major procedures: preoperatively 50 international units/kg IV to achieve a rise of approximately 100% of normal of antihemophilic factor VIII prior to surgery; repeat infusions every 6 to 12 hours initially as needed and for a total of 10 to 14 days until healing is complete

3.title: Indications
3.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • Bleeding - Hemophilia A
  • Bleeding - Hemophilia A - Surgical procedure

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: specific contraindications have not been determined

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• human plasma product; may contain infectious agents including viruses and theoretical risk of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease agent
  • pregnant women and immunocompromised patients; parvovirus B19 transmission presents a more serious risk
  • report suspected transmission of infection to Talecris Biotherapeutics 1-800-520-2807

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono:
• Antihemophilic Factor: WHO: Compatible with breastfeeding.
  • Antihemophilic Factor: Micromedex: Infant risk is minimal.

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Antihemophilic Factor VIII Human is a dried concentrate of human Factor VIII, which facilitates the activation of Factor X ultimately causing the formation of thrombin and fibrin promoting platelet aggregation and adhesion to damaged vascular endothelium.

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Intravenous
  • for IV administration only by either direct syringe injection or drip infusion
  • before reconstitution, warm supplied diluent to room temperature
  • during reconstitution, aim stream of diluent at a 45 degree angle against the side of vial to minimize foaming
  • administer using a filter needle
  • administer within 3 hours of reconstitution
  • administer at a rate tolerated by patient, usually entire dose in 5 to 10 minutes is well-tolerated

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• plasma factor VIII levels; prior to administration to confirm cause of clotting disorder, and serial levels during treatment to determine adequate response, especially in the setting of surgical prophylaxis and severe bleeding
  • factor VIII inhibitor (neutralizing antibodies) levels; if inadequate response to appropriate doses
  • control of bleeding is indicative of efficacy
  • hematocrit levels and direct Coombs test; patients with blood type A, B, or AB receiving large or frequently repeated doses

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Drug is made from human plasma. Despite screening and testing, human plasma products carry a risk of transmitting infectious agents. Risks and benefits should be discussed with patient by healthcare provider, and patients receiving repeated/regular therapy should consider appropriate vaccinations when possible (ie, hepatitis A and B).
  • Drug may cause headache, dizziness, dysgeusia, pyrexia, and infusion-site inflammation.
  • Instruct patients to report spontaneous bleeding episodes, as this may indicate the development of inhibitory antibodies against factor VIII.
  • Instruct patient to report signs/symptoms of hepatitis A (several days to weeks of poor appetite, tiredness, and low-grade fever followed by nausea, vomiting, and pain in the belly). Dark urine and a yellowed complexion may also occur.
  • Advise pregnant women or immune compromised individuals of the signs/symptoms of Parvovirus B19 (eg, fever, drowsiness, chills, and runny nose followed about two weeks later by a rash, and joint pain).
  • Advise patient to discontinue use and immediately report signs/symptoms of hypersensitivity reactions (eg, hives, urticaria, facial edema, flushing, nausea, chest tightness, wheezing, dyspnea, hypotension, and anaphylaxis).
